Literature Review: Model-based clustering has been a cornerstone of unsupervised machine learning for over six decades, with its roots in statistical modeling and inference. The task of clustering, which involves automatically grouping observations into homogeneous clusters, has been a subject of intense research in the field of machine learning. In contrast to heuristic approaches, model-based clustering provides a principled and reproducible approach to clustering, allowing for robust parameter estimation and objective inference on the number of clusters. This review aims to provide an overview of the theory underpinning model-based clustering, outline associated inferential approaches, and highlight recent methodological developments that facilitate the use of model-based clustering for a broad array of data types.
